comments.body: `git checkout -b feature-xxx --track upstream/da-master` should do the same thing in one command.

You'd think so but in fact it creates a tracking branch.
```
Branch 'feature-xxx' set up to track remote branch 'da-master' from 'upstream'.
Switched to a new branch 'feature-xxx'
```
I'll change this to 
```
git checkout -t upstream/da-master
git checkout -b feature-xxx da-master
```
for clarity.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +223,227 @@git fetch upstream da-master
git checkout -t upstream/da-master
git checkout -b feature-xxx da-master
git push upstream feature-xxx:feature-xxx
```

comments.body:
```suggestion
git push upstream feature-xxx
```
Makes it easier to not have a typo in one of the branch names.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +224,228 @@git checkout -t upstream/da-master
git checkout -b feature-xxx da-master
git push upstream feature-xxx:feature-xxx
```
where `feature-xxx` is replaced by the desired name of your feature branch.
